se.softhouse.common.guavaextensions

Class Predicates2

  • java.lang.Object
    • se.softhouse.common.guavaextensions.Predicates2

  • @Immutable
public final class Predicates2
extends Object
    Additional implementations of the Predicate interface, as a complement to Predicates

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Static Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      static <T> com.google.common.base.Predicate<? super T> and(com.google.common.base.Predicate<? super T> first, com.google.common.base.Predicate<? super T> second)
      Works just like Predicates.and(Predicate, Predicate) except that if first is Predicates.alwaysTrue() second is returned directly (or vice versa).
      static <E> com.google.common.base.Predicate<List<? extends E>> listPredicate(com.google.common.base.Predicate<E> elementLimiter)
      Returns a predicate that throws an IllegalArgumentException if any element in a list doesn't return true for elementLimiter.apply(Object).

      • Methods inherited from class java.lang.Object

        clone, equals, finalize, getClass, hashCode, notify, notifyAll, toString, wait, wait, wait

    • Method Detail

      • and

        public static <T> com.google.common.base.Predicate<? super T> and(com.google.common.base.Predicate<? super T> first,
                                                                  com.google.common.base.Predicate<? super T> second)
        Works just like Predicates.and(Predicate, Predicate) except that if first is Predicates.alwaysTrue() second is returned directly (or vice versa). This has the potential to make Object.toString() look a bit nicer for the resulting Predicate.

      • listPredicate

        public static <E> com.google.common.base.Predicate<List<? extends E>> listPredicate(com.google.common.base.Predicate<E> elementLimiter)
        Returns a predicate that throws an IllegalArgumentException if any element in a list doesn't return true for elementLimiter.apply(Object). Useful for input validation where you already have a Predicate for the element type and want to check a list of such elements. Without listPredicate(Predicate) it would look something like: 
         
 List<Integer> numbers = Arrays.asList(1, -1, -2);
 Optional<Integer> invalidNumber = Iterables.tryFind(numbers, Predicates.not(ABOVE_ZERO));
 if(invalidNumber.isPresent())
   throw new IllegalArgumentException("'" + invalidNumber.get() + "' is not " + ABOVE_ZERO);
        With listPredicate(Predicate): 
         
 Predicates2.listPredicate(ABOVE_ZERO).apply(numbers);
        As this breaks the general contract of Predicate.apply(Object) it should be considered useful for validating arguments only. The detail message only mentions the first element that didn't return true.
